conclusion: There are four objects above the slabs, which are illuminated with a light source, casting A, B, C and D on the ground.
Let me analyze how shadows A, B, C, and D would change when the light source moves backwards (away from the objects).
A decorative bird cage with shadow A.
Shadow B appears to be cast by the same object as A (from a different angle).
A wall lamp with shadow C.
A decorative cross or sword with shadow D.
The light source is currently illuminating these objects, creating the shadows on the stone slab floor.
When a light source moves backward (away from objects): Shadow size increases, Shadow position moves further from the object, Shadow edges become less defined/more blurry.

premise: Shadow A is relatively sharp and positioned directly beneath/beside the bird cage.
conclusion: When the light moves backward, Shadow A will enlarge, move further away from the bird cage, and the edges will become less defined.

premise: Shadow B appears to be another shadow from the bird cage from a different angle.
conclusion: When the light moves backward, Shadow B will grow larger, extend further from the object, and the edges will become less distinct.

premise: Shadow C is a fairly defined shadow from the lamp.
conclusion: When the light moves backward, Shadow C will increase in size, extend further away from the lamp, and become less sharp around the edges.

premise: Shadow D is a defined shadow from the decorative item.
conclusion: When the light moves backward, Shadow D will enlarge, move further from the object, and the shadow boundaries will become more diffuse.

premise: When the light source moves backward, all shadows (A, B, C, and D) will increase in size, move further away from their respective objects, and all shadow edges will become less defined and more blurry.
conclusion: The relative positions of the shadows to each other will generally remain the same, but they will all expand outward from their current positions.
